title: Jason Rhoades
text:
Jason Rhoades (July 9, 1965 – August 1, 2006) was an American <a href="installation%20art">installation art</a>ist. Better known in Europe, where he exhibited regularly for the last twelve years of his life, Rhoades was celebrated for his combination dinner party/<a href="Art%20exhibition">exhibition</a>s that feature violet neon signs (a form of <a href="word%20art">word art</a>) with African, Caribbean, Creole and <a href="hip%20hop%20music">hip hop</a> slang for the <a href="female%20genitalia">female genitalia</a>. His work remains part of the permanent collection in the Rubell Family Collection in <a href="Miami">Miami</a>, where he was a part of exhibit "Beg Borrow and Steal" at the time of his death.
Life.
He was married to Australian-born artist <a href="Rachel%20Khedoori">Rachel Khedoori</a> and they had daughter named Rubi.
Rhoades received his <a href="Master%20of%20Fine%20Arts">MFA</a> from <a href="UCLA">UCLA</a> in 1993 after studying at the <a href="California%20College%20of%20the%20Arts">California College of the Arts</a> in <a href="Oakland%2C%20California">Oakland</a>, the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Art%20Institute">San Francisco Art Institute</a> and the <a href="Skowhegan%20School%20of%20Painting%20and%20Sculpture">Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture</a>.
Rhoades died August 1, 2006 in Los Angeles of heart failure.
Notes.
Diane Haithman. "Artist's death ruled accidental <a href="http%3A//www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-et-quick7.4oct07%2C1%2C1973109.story"></a>", "Los Angeles Times", October 7, 2006
